content.description:
Start on a mossy slab towards the middle of the wall and head up into the crack system. First pitch is 40m, second is about 15m. Both pitches sit around 5.8, although the guide book claims 10a for the second pitch...? I Easiest climb on the wall, nice and long. Either walk off the top or double rope rappel to the ground - 2 60m ropes will just reach it.

Left on the mossy slab in the middle of the main wall. 
14 draws + anchors.

climbs.name: Fair Warning
climbs.fa: Dave LePard, Travis Munch, Mike Fiddler, 2000

content.description:
Generously bolted climb with careful movement on decent edges.

Obvious bolt line up the center of the main wall, just right of Electric Doughnut. Nice climb. 
8 bolts? I forget, count them. + anchors

climbs.name: Left, Right, and Wrong
climbs.fa: Allen Agopsowicz, Mark Phillips, Jo-Ann Richards, 2002

content.description:
Shares the start of Brackyramphus (10b) before moving right onto the darker colored face, staying clear of the crack on the left. The bolt line moves right pretty early, but one of the clips puts your rope in a pretty bad spot hooked around a flakey edge. Consider using the Brakyramphus bolts until the lines truly separate a bit higher on the wall. Easier start turns into long reaches and small feet. Pretty fun!

If you're at least 150 lbs and 6 feet tall you can baaaarely manage a single rope rappel using a 70m rope (tie knots in the end of your rope). If that makes you nervous, bring up a second rope or just climb the second pitch of Electric Doughnut to top out as well. 

First bolt line to the left of Electric Doughnut, starts by mounting a small roof. 
12-13 draws + anchors

Sugarloaf is a secluded crag in about 15km outside of Victoria and hosts a number of routes 5.8 to 5.11. Rock is generally solid, but could use some cleaning in some spots. All but two of the routes are fully bolted. Great for doing long, moderate sport climbs up to 40-45 meters. Two pitches bring many of the routes to the top of the wall, which you can walk off. At the top you get beautiful views of the Olympic range and Sooke basin. The first pitch of many of these climbs is in the 40m range, so having two ropes with you is smart if you're not planning on topping out. Bring your 70m if you've got it.
